predictions.reasoning: Strong signals: (1) has_maintainer_label=true (90.7% merge rate baseline), (2) author joshp123 has 100% prior merge rate (3/3), (3) maintainer has already merged via fast-forward (visible in comments: 'Merged to main via fast-forward'), (4) positive testing/validation from contributors (jiulingyun), (5) active maintainer engagement. Draft status is minor negative but overridden by other signals.

Strong negative signals: (1) author alberthild has 0% merge rate (0/2 prior PRs), (2) size:L label historically drops hard in merge rate, (3) competing approach in comments (ashbrener mentions rclone alternative #19052), (4) infrastructure/dependency-heavy NATS JetStream approach may face organizational resistance. Moderate: greptile reviewed but no approval. Some positive: battle-tested claim (157k events), comprehensive test suite. However, low-merge-rate author + competing solution + L-size = rejection likely.

Strong closure signal: author self-closed with explicit reasoning 'Closing: 13 files across auth boundary is too broad for a single PR.' This indicates recognized scope/review burden. Negative factors: (1) is_low_merge_author=true (hclsys: 1/9 prior = 11.1%), (2) greptile identified P0 sandbox auth bug that author claims fixed but reasoning unclear, (3) broad file scope (13 files across sensitive browser/auth boundary) creates risk. However, closure is author-initiated and acknowledged, suggesting quality-aware triage.

Author self-closed with technical justification: 'the existing regex already matches rate_limit_exceeded' + 'real fix belongs upstream in pi-ai'. This indicates: (1) duplicate/redundant fix, (2) author recognizes upstream is proper location, (3) first-time contributor (0 prior PRs) attempting fix that already exists. Minimal scope (1 file) but closure is warranted based on technical analysis.

Author self-closed with explicit reason: 'Closing — guard already addressed by upstream refactoring.' This is a duplicate/superseded fix. Negative factors: (1) is_low_merge_author=true (0xRaini: 3/41 = 7.3%), (2) security-adjacent nature creates caution, (3) upstream already fixed. Positive: author proactively closed when recognized upstream addressed it, suggesting responsible behavior. CI green but fix is no longer needed.

Strong merge signals: (1) author lailoo has solid 32.1% merge rate (9/28), (2) size:S label historically stronger, (3) maintainer comment indicates successful merge upstream: 'now merged' + references #14786 with full implementation details, (4) feature is GLM-5 forward-compat which is model infrastructure (strategic), (5) greptile reviewed. Comment from steipete (CONTRIBUTOR) explicitly states '(now merged)' — this PR appears to have already merged or superseded by #14786.

Author self-closed with clear intent: 'Recreated from clean branch as #19111' — this is a superseded PR, author manually recreated in cleaner form. Negative: (1) is_low_merge_author=true (Clawborn: 0/10 = 0%), (2) has_trusted_contributor_label present but no merge history, suggesting label doesn't guarantee success. Positive: (1) size:S, (2) greptile reviewed, (3) author's proactive recreation shows responsibility. Closure is intentional/expected, not a rejection.

Author self-closed with strategic pivot: 'Closing this PR in favor of a standalone plugin approach' + published to npm as @vainplex/nats-eventstore. This is intentional supersession, not rejection. However, if treated as independent PR: (1) is_low_merge_author=true (alberthild: 0/3), (2) size:XL is hard ceiling, (3) community suggestion to move to plugin (HenryLoenwind). Author's closure is voluntary/strategic, showing market-aware decision-making. The merged version likely exists as plugin, not in main.

Positive signals: (1) author MisterGuy420 has strong 60% merge rate (6/10), (2) size:S, (3) has_trusted_contributor_label=true, (4) files are documentation/config (AGENTS.md, BOOTSTRAP.md, etc.) — low-risk changes. Minimal concern: (1) no comments/reviews visible but doc-only PRs often skip review, (2) description is vague ('fix: short description'). Trust signal from high prior merge rate + trusted-contributor label outweighs lack of visibility.

Multiple decisive closure signals: (1) Author TheAmSpeed is first-time contributor (0 prior PRs), (2) Automated closure by openclaw-barnacle with explicit reason: 'Closing this PR because it looks dirty (too many unrelated commits)' repeated 10 times across comments, (3) size:XL (261 files) is historically hard reject, (4) touches_multiple_channels=true + massive file scope across unrelated subsystems (IC memory vault spanning all channels, web-ui, gateway, cli, commands, agents), (5) architecture violation of separation of concerns. This is textbook scope-creep rejection.
Explicitly closed by maintainer (grp06) as duplicate of #8815. Member noted: 'currently CONFLICTING with main and has failing CI'. Conflicting state + duplicate + failing CI = deterministic closure.

Minimal, focused fix (2 files, preferred solution per maintainer). Supersedes #2395. Small scope targets specific OpenRouter model reference bug. Author has 4 prior PRs (zero merge history, but focused scope overcomes this). No CI failures noted. XS/S category historically stronger. Greptile review present but no blocking feedback.

Single-file bug fix with clear business justification (batch jobs failing due to insufficient error context). Minimal scope (1 file) in agents category (top merge category at 1161 PRs). Author provided context: model lacks error explanation. No blocking CI/conflict signals. Low complexity + clear value = merge likely.

Single-file targeted fix in commands category. Symlink resolution issue in doctor command is narrow, low-risk change. No CI failures, no conflicts noted. First-time contributor but scope is minimal and focused. Maintainer engagement pattern absent (no blocking signals).
Author explicitly closed PR stating root cause already fixed in main by refactoring into schema.hints.ts. Self-closed with maintainer acknowledgment. Changes declared 'no longer necessary'.

Author (xinhuagu) explicitly closed stating 'fixed upstream in main'. Clear upstream resolution. Author has moderate track record (7 prior PRs, 28.6% merge rate) but closure is intentional/self-driven.

Single-file performance/correctness fix: prevents cron spin loop (high-value bug fix). XS size, includes test coverage (2 files: test + implementation). No blocking signals. First-time contributor but narrow, well-scoped change addresses real edge case.

Medium-scope skills prompt bloat fix (4 files, M size). Agents category (high volume = 1161 PRs). Includes tests + config changes. Automated Codex review present (suggests engagement). Author has 1 prior PR (zero merge history is slight negative). M-sized PRs have ~19% peak merge rate per guidelines, but fix targets important bloat issue + test coverage helps.

Small-scope validation fix (2 files, S size). Multi-agent session path validation correctness issue. Author xinhuagu has solid track record: 8 prior PRs, 25% merge rate (above baseline). Includes test coverage. S-sized PRs historically stronger merge (~24%). No blocking signals.

Author (andrey-esipov) explicitly states 'Superseded — will resubmit after formatting fix'. Self-closure is intentional, author plans to resubmit. XS scope in CLI category, but current PR is abandoned.

Author explicitly closed PR with comment 'Closing - PR created without explicit owner approval.' This is a self-closed PR, not a merge. First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with no merge history. Greptile review flagged type signature issues but author chose not to pursue. Early signal of abandonment.

Experienced author with 66.7% prior merge rate (2/3 PRs merged). Small scope (2 files, agents category). Focused on skills metadata parsing. Greptile review present but no major blockers evident. Above-baseline merge likelihood for established contributors.

Large XL PR (24 files) with heavy engagement (32 comments, 48 reviews). Author is engaged CONTRIBUTOR actively addressing Greptile review comments across 4+ review cycles, demonstrating commitment and iterative fixes (GCP validation, Zod schema alignment, error typing). Multi-category (docs, gateway, cli) indicates broad scope. High comment + maintainer engagement signals quality iteration, but XL size penalizes merge likelihood. Greptile review presence and author responsiveness pushes above 50% baseline despite size risk.

First-time contributor adding new AI provider (AIsa) with multi-category coverage (docs, commands, agents). 13 files is moderate scope. Feature addition to core provider system likely valuable for user base. Greptile review present. However, 0% prior merge rate as first-time author creates uncertainty. No explicit maintainer engagement yet, but provider additions are common merge candidates.

Touches multiple channels (discord, matrix, slack, telegram, feishu) = high-risk per AGENTS.md guidance. Maintainer label present but negative comment overrides. PR appears to have failed quality bar.

Greptile review found 3 issues. This appears to be a resubmission attempt without substantive changes. Combined with PR#14194, signals author struggle with project standards.

Author's own comment states PR was 'Merged with squash into main'. This is post-hoc confirmation of merge. Author is experienced (11 prior PRs, 36.4% merge rate). Member involvement + documented rebase path = approval already executed. Addresses issue #9790 (string coercion for allowlist). 7 files across agents + cli with test coverage. The `forced` flag is now unused. This is superseded/duplicate fix of broader refactor. Author chose to close recognizing supersession.

Minimal scope (1 file). Author's track record = near-guaranteed approval. Documentation maintenance by trusted maintainer.

duplicates.evidence: Both authored by alberthild; both implement NATS JetStream event-store infrastructure for agents/gateway. Identical file signatures: docs/concepts/event-store.md, src/config/types.eventstore.ts, src/config/types.openclaw.ts, src/config/zod-schema.ts, src/gateway/server-close.ts, src/gateway/server.impl.ts, src/infra/__test__/event-store.helpers.ts, src/infra/event-store.test.ts, src/infra/event-store.ts, src/types/nats.d.ts (11/11 overlap). PR #18171 explicitly closes in favor of standalone plugin; PR #7358 likely earlier version. Both are competing implementations of same feature.

All three are author-initiated closures with explicit reasoning about upstream fixes or supersession: (1) #13445: 'real fix belongs upstream in pi-ai' (2) #13766: 'guard already addressed by upstream refactoring' (3) #16934: 'Recreated from clean branch as #19111' — indicates batch of submissions where author discovered fix already exists or recreated cleanly. All are small-scope, first or low-success-rate authors encountering redundancy.

PR #2395 explicitly closed by maintainer grp06 as duplicate of #8815. Both address OpenRouter auto/default model reference issue. #8815 is preferred 'minimal, focused fix'. #2395 includes additional unrelated skills-install changes and is conflicting with main.

Both authored by xinhuagu, both small-scope fixes in overlapping areas (gateway WebUI + sessions). However, distinct issues (scope/CORS vs path validation). Weak signal; likely independent PRs from same author.

Identical author (jhs129), submitted 58 seconds apart (2026-02-11T17:09:55Z vs 17:10:43Z). Identical file lists (49 files, exact same paths). Identical labels (docs, app: web-ui, gateway, scripts, docker). Same vague title 'Skills'. Same size/scope. PR#14195 has one fewer prior PR merged (0/4 vs 0/3 at submission). This is a resubmission attempt, likely after author realized first submission had issues. Both should be closed as duplicates; PR#14195 should be closed in favor of #14194 if either is to proceed.

PR#16384 author explicitly states superseded by PR#16411 in commit comment. Same author (ciberponk), same fix topic (CJK sentence punctuation in block chunker), same files modified. PR#16384 is the non-English version, PR#16411 is the 'English re-submission'. PR#16384 is already closed/superseded.

Both PRs from author chetaniitbhilai (0% merge rate) opened 1 day apart (Feb 17 06:23 vs 07:59). Nearly identical scope: both XL (~1120 files), both touch ALL channels + extensions, both flagged by bot for 'too many unrelated commits', both closed by openclaw-barnacle with identical closure message repeated 10x. PR #19018 is titled 'noramlising' (typo variant) of #18948 'normalising'. Clear re-attempt after first rejection.

PR #9832 contains xAI + DeepSeek + tagline + package.json changes (20 files). Member grp06 explicitly states 'I narrowed this down to xAI-only and opened a replacement PR: #9885. Rationale: Drops unrelated tagline + package.json gate changes, Drops DeepSeek entirely, Leaves only xAI...'. PR #9832 closed with 'Closing this PR to avoid duplicate review.' Clear supersession: #9885 is intended replacement with narrower scope.

Author of #10412 explicitly states: 'Closing — the fixes in this PR (overdue job catch-up on restart, timer re-arm on early return, post-recompute due-job sweep) have been fully addressed by #10776, which landed a more comprehensive cron reliability overhaul covering the same root causes.' While #10776 is not in this batch, #10412 is confirmed superseded/duplicate.

Iterative version chain (v3→v4→v5→v6 in titles). Explicit duplicate signal from reviewer @striking: 'appears duplicative with PR #13906 (very similar changes)'. Author 0xRaini self-confirms: 'same fix, slightly cleaner'. Same category (agents), narrow scope. Reviewer recommends closing one.

Both PRs target doctor env-template/env-var preservation in config writes (same category: commands, same file overlap: src/commands/doctor.ts + src/commands/doctor-config-flow.ts). #10254 created 2026-02-06 08:15, #10342 created 2026-02-06 10:35 (2h20m gap). #10254 has 6 comments showing active iteration; #10342 should be superseded by #10254's resolution.

Both PRs address 'prevent inline commands from being handled twice' in Signal channel. PR #3124 (travisp, first-time contributor) vs PR #10575 (heyhudson, 100% merge rate). Both modify identical files: src/auto-reply/reply/get-reply-inline-actions.ts. PR #10575 explicitly mentions '#10556' reference and includes regression test. PR #3124 appears earlier (2026-01-28) but #10575 (2026-02-06) is the accepted version with author approval and maintainer engagement. #3124 was closed in favor of #10575.

Both involve crash/failure recovery mechanisms (watchdog timer vs delivery queue). Both touch cron/infra timing. However, scope differs: #10762 is cron watchdog (superseded by #10776, not #15636), while #15636 is outbound delivery queue for crash recovery. Not direct duplicates but share architectural concern (resilience). Low confidence — likely distinct features.

Both close with author stating upstream PR already fixed the issue. #13382 → superseded by #17150 (idempotency keys). #10762 → superseded by #10776 (timer clamp). Similar pattern but different root causes and upstream PRs. Low confidence — no direct overlap, just both resolved by upstream work.

PR #16921 author self-closes: 'Closing — overlaps with #8078 which addresses the same class of issue.' Both are proto-pollution security fixes in merge-config. Canonical fix is #8078.

Both address Slack thread_ts string handling. #11194 has additional validation (`threadId != null && threadId !== ""`) addressing concerns raised by Greptile review in #4389.

Both are first-time contributor fixes from non-members touching similar areas (commands/auto-reply message handling). Both have Greptile P1-level concerns flagged in reviews.
